texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recently tossed Ubuntu 8.10 on my Mac Mini at home to use it as a home theater PC (with  Boxee ). When I connected to my wireless network via NetworkManager, I entered my WPA2 passphrase, and then I was prompted to enter a password for gnome-keyring. I went back to the couch, SSH'ed in, and continued configuring it remotely. When it rebooted, it never came back online.
texts.text: I recently tossed Ubuntu 8.10 on my Mac Mini at home to use it as a home theater PC (with  Boxee ). When I connected to my wireless network via NetworkManager, I entered my WPA2 passphrase, and then I was prompted to enter a password for gnome-keyring. I went back to the couch, SSH'ed in, and continued configuring it remotely. When it rebooted, it never came back online.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once I switched the TV back over to the Mini, I saw that gnome-keyring had popped up and it was asking for my password. I entered it, and the Mini joined the wireless network. Each time I rebooted, I had to go through this procedure (which is annoying to do with a HTPC that is across the room). I found a  pretty fancy solution , but it looked a little complicated for my setup.
texts.text: Once I switched the TV back over to the Mini, I saw that gnome-keyring had popped up and it was asking for my password. I entered it, and the Mini joined the wireless network. Each time I rebooted, I had to go through this procedure (which is annoying to do with a HTPC that is across the room). I found a  pretty fancy solution , but it looked a little complicated for my setup.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's how I did it in a simpler way in Ubuntu 8.10:
texts.text: Here's how I did it in a simpler way in Ubuntu 8.10:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Enter your current password in the top box, but leave the bottom two boxes blank
texts.text: Enter your current password in the top box, but leave the bottom two boxes blank

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you reboot your machine, it should not ask for a password for your keyring any longer. This allowed my system to log into my wireless network automatically.
texts.text: If you reboot your machine, it should not ask for a password for your keyring any longer. This allowed my system to log into my wireless network automatically.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: WHOA THERE:  Since the only password being stored on the device is my WPA2 password, I'm not concerned about the security of the keyring. If you're doing this on a laptop or desktop that other people use, I would highly recommend not following these steps. All of your passwords and keys will be stored unencrypted.
texts.text: WHOA THERE:  Since the only password being stored on the device is my WPA2 password, I'm not concerned about the security of the keyring. If you're doing this on a laptop or desktop that other people use, I would highly recommend not following these steps. All of your passwords and keys will be stored unencrypted.
